snippet: On the eve of a visit by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it was open to a so-called zero option when the NATO combat mission there ends.
abstract: Obama administration says that it is open to so-called zero option that would involve leaving no American troops in Afghanistan after 2014, on eve of visit by Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai; military analysts have said it is difficult to conceive of how United States can achieve its post-2014 goals in Afghanistan with no troop presence, suggesting that White House is staking out negotiating position with Karzai and Pentagon.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

lead_paragraph: On the eve of a visit by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it was open to a so-called zero option when the NATO combat mission there ends.

headline.seo: U.S. Is Open to Withdraw Afghan Force After 2014
headline.main: U.S. Is Open to Withdraw Afghan Force After 2014
headline.print_headline: U.S. Is Open To Withdraw Afghan Force After 2014
